results.title: Some call it progress
results.creator_credit: Tina Viljoen, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The wrecking-ball is a most effective instrument of change. It levels buildings to permit the construction of highrises and freeways. Slowly, the sense of identity that people feel in places inherited from the past is being shattered by the drive to modernize. This film chooses looks at Montreal, Brussels & Sydney, where unrestricted development has been resisted with varying degrees of success. Voice and narration by Bronwyn Drainie.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tina Viljoen, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Development without tears?
results.creator_credit: Tina Viljoen, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: One-third of the world’s people live in the rural areas of the Middle East, Asia and Africa. Although industrial development programs have vastly improved life in the cities, Third World countries are now faced with the need to revitalize their rural societies. The question is how to accomplish that. Each of these nations now realizes it must find its own answers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tina Viljoen, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Physical education activities for the classroom
results.creator_credit: Ian Andrews and Simon Fraser University

results.title: New breath of life. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Bob Berk, Frank Gardonyi, David Adams and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: Revised version of Film no 505488. Shows first aid techniques to use when people are choking. Notes the methods of opening the airway, dislodging foreign objects, and mouth-to-mouth breathing.

results.title: The French solution
results.creator_credit: Gordon Stewart, Maxine Crook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Emphasises the importance of daily physical education for children. Outlines the experiments conducted in France and Canada on daily activity for children and notes parents’ and children’s responses to exposure to physical education on a daily basis. Suitable for teacher/tertiary level.
